case_vignette: A 45-year-old man with asthma comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and cough. He also has a history of chronic sinusitis and foot drop. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and inhaled corticosteroid. Physical examination shows diffuse wheezing over both lung fields and tender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 23,000/mm3 with 26% eosinophils and a serum creatinine of 1.7 mg/dL. Urine microscopy shows red blood cell casts.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

No, I do not have any known history of kidney disease.

No, I haven't experienced any chest pain or discomfort.

Yes, I have a history of asthma.

No, I do not smoke and have not smoked in the past.

No, I have not had any exposure to pollutants, allergens, or occupational hazards that could affect my breathing.

No, I have not observed any changes in the color of my sputum, nor do I cough up blood.

No, I have not experienced any recent weight loss or night sweats.

No, I do not have difficulty breathing while lying flat, nor do I need to prop myself up with pillows to breathe easier at night.
Final Diagnosis: Asthma exacerbation
